lines.content: * Represents the main entry point of the Alpha task manager application.
* This console-based application supports various commands to manage tasks:
* listing, marking, unmarking, creating, and deleting different types of tasks
* (ToDo, Deadline, Event). It also handles the saving and loading of tasks.
* Handles all user interaction (input and output) within the application.
* Responsible for saving and loading tasks from the storage file.
* Maintains and manipulates the list of tasks in memory.
* Constructs an instance of {@code Alpha}, initializing the user interface,
* Continuously reads user commands from the standard input and executes them
* until the "bye" command is encountered. Supported commands include:

*
  • mark <index>: Mark the task at the specified index.

*
  • unmark <index>: Unmark the task at the specified index.

*
  • delete <index>: Delete the task at the specified index.
* If an invalid command is entered or if an exception occurs while processing
* a command, an error message is displayed.
System.out.println(" OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I don't know what that means :-(");
System.out.println(" OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I don't know what that means :-(");
* Launches the Alpha application by creating an {@code Alpha} instance
* @param args Command-line arguments (not used in this application).
* Manages data persistence for the Alpha application by reading and writing
* tasks to an external file. This class provides methods to save a list of
* tasks and load them back into memory.
* Represents the current working directory of the user.
private static final Path HOME = Paths.get("").toAbsolutePath();
* Path to the directory where data files will be stored.
private static final Path DATA_PATH = HOME.resolve("data");
* Path to the specific data file where tasks are saved.
private static final Path FILE_PATH = DATA_PATH.resolve("alpha.txt");
* Constructs a {@code Storage} object for handling task data.
* Saves the provided list of tasks to the data file. If the directories
* do not exist, they are created automatically before writing.
* @param tasks The list of tasks to be written to the file.
* Loads tasks from the data file into memory. If the file does not exist,
* an empty list of tasks is returned.
* @return A list of tasks read from the data file.
* Converts a task into a string format suitable for saving to the data file.
* @param task The task to be converted.
* @return A formatted string representing the task data.
* Parses a single line of text to reconstruct the corresponding task object.
* @param line A formatted string representing a task.
* @return The {@code Task} object derived from the given string,
*         or {@code null} if the line is invalid or cannot be parsed.
* Handles user interface interactions for the Alpha application.
* It offers methods to display greeting and exit messages.
* Prints a greeting message to welcome the user.
System.out.println(" What can I do for you?");
* Prints a farewell message when the application is about to close.
System.out.println(" Bye. Hope to see you soon!");
* Represents a task with a specific deadline.
* In addition to a name (inherited from {@link Task}),
* this class maintains a {@code deadline} string.
* The deadline or due date associated with this task.
private static final DateTimeFormatter INPUT_FORMAT = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("yyyy-MM-dd HHmm");
private static final DateTimeFormatter OUTPUT_FORMAT = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM d yyyy, h:mma",
* Constructs a new {@code Deadline} task with the specified
* @param taskName The name or description of the task.
* @param deadline The deadline or due date for the task.
throw new IllegalArgumentException("Invalid date format. Use yyyy-MM-dd HHmm");
* Returns a string representation of this deadline task,
* including the task type indicator [D], the base task
* @return A string describing this deadline task, for example:
* Returns a string in the format used to store this task in a file.
* Typically used by the application to save tasks to disk.
* @return A string combining the task name and deadline, separated by " | ".
* Represents an event which occurs within a specific time range.
* In addition to a name (inherited from {@link Task}),
* this class maintains a start time and an end time.
private static final DateTimeFormatter INPUT_FORMAT = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("yyyy-MM-dd HHmm");
private static final DateTimeFormatter OUTPUT_FORMAT = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM d yyyy, h:mma")
* The start time of this event.
* The end time of this event.
* Constructs a new {@code Event} task with the specified
* task name, start time, and end time.
* @param taskName The name or description of the event.
* @param from The starting time of the event.
* @param to The ending time of the event.
public Event(String taskName, String from, String to) {
throw new IllegalArgumentException("Invalid date format. Use yyyy-MM-dd HHmm");
* Returns a string representation of this event, including
* the task type indicator [E], the base task description
* (from {@link Task#toString()}), and the time range in a
* @return A string describing this event, for example:
* Returns a string in the format used to store this event in a file.
* Typically used by the application to save tasks to disk.
* @return A string combining the task name, start time, and end time,
* Represents a generic task with a name and a completion status.
* The name or description of this task.
* Indicates whether this task is marked as done.
* Constructs a new {@code Task} with the specified name.
* The task is initially not done.
* @param taskName The name or description of the task.
* Returns whether this task is marked as done.
* @return {@code true} if the task is marked as done; {@code false} otherwise.
* Unmarks this task (marks it as not done).
* Returns a string representation of this task, indicating
* whether it is done or not.

*
  • {@code "[X] Task Name"} if it is done.

*
  • {@code "[ ] Task Name"} if it is not done.
* Represents a list of tasks. Provides methods to add, remove, and modify tasks.
* Constructs a {@code TaskList} instance by loading tasks from storage.
* @param storage The storage handler to load tasks from.
* Adds a new task to the list and displays a confirmation message.
* @param task The task to be added.
System.out.println(" Got it. I've added this task:");
System.out.println(" Now you have " + tasks.size() + " tasks in the list.");
* Displays all tasks in the list.
* If the list is empty, an appropriate message is shown.
System.out.println(" Here are the task book:");
* Marks a task as done based on its index.
* @param index The index of the task to mark as done.
System.out.println(" This task has already been marked.");
System.out.println(" Nice! I've marked this task as done:");
* Unmarks a task as not done based on its index.
* @param index The index of the task to unmark.
System.out.println(" This task has already been unmarked.");
System.out.println(" OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:");
* Deletes a task from the list based on its index.
* @param index The index of the task to delete.
Task removedTask = tasks.remove(index); // Remove the task
System.out.println(" Noted. I've removed this task:");
System.out.println(" Now you have " + tasks.size() + " tasks in the list.");
* Finds tasks that contain the given keyword.
System.out.println(" Here are the matching tasks in your list:");
* Represents a simple to-do task without a specific deadline or time range.
* Constructs a new {@code ToDo} task with the specified name.
* @param taskName The name or description of the to-do task.
* Returns a string representation of this to-do task,
* including the task type indicator [T] followed
* by the base task description (from {@link Task#toString()}).
* @return A string describing this to-do task, for example:
* Returns a string in the format used to store this to-do task in a file.
* Typically used by the application to save tasks to disk.
* @return A string containing only the task name.
private final ByteArrayOutputStream outputStream = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
assertTrue(consoleOutput.contains("Hello! I'm Alpha"), "Program startup greeting is missing.");
assertTrue(consoleOutput.contains("Got it. I've added this task:"), "Task addition message is missing.");
assertTrue(consoleOutput.contains("[T][ ] Read book"), "Task was not added correctly.");
assertTrue(consoleOutput.contains("Here are the task book"), "Task list message is missing.");
assertTrue(consoleOutput.contains("Bye. Hope to see you soon!"), "Exit message is missing.");
assertEquals(1, tasks.size(), "Task list should contain 1 task");
assertEquals(todo, tasks.get(0), "The first task should be 'Read book'");
